ud6.4:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ud6.4:1.3: Now at that time several ascetics, brahmins, and wanderers who followed various other religions were residing in Sāvatthī, holding different views, beliefs, and opinions, relying on different views.
ud6.4:2.1: There were some ascetics and brahmins who had this doctrine and view:
ud6.4:2.2: “The cosmos is eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.”
ud6.4:3.1: Others held views such as the following, each regarding their own view as true and others as silly.
ud6.4:6.2: “The soul and the body are one and the same.”
ud6.4:7.2: “The soul is one thing, the body another.”
ud6.4:8.2: “A realized one still exists after death.”
ud6.4:9.2: “A realized one no longer exists after death.”
ud6.4:10.2: “A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death.”
ud6.4:11.2: “A realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death.”
ud6.4:12.1: They were fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words:
ud6.4:12.2: “Such is Truth, such is not Truth!
ud6.4:12.3: Such is not Truth, such is Truth!”
ud6.4:13.1: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
ud6.4:13.2: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening. The Buddha said:
ud6.4:16.1: “The wanderers of other religions are blind and sightless.
ud6.4:16.2: They don’t understand what is beneficial or what is not beneficial, nor what is the truth and what is not the truth.
ud6.4:16.3: That’s why they are fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
ud6.4:17.1: Once upon a time, mendicants, right here in Sāvatthī there was a certain king.
ud6.4:17.2: Then the king addressed a man,
ud6.4:17.3: ‘Please, worthy man, gather all those blind from birth throughout Sāvatthī and bring them together in one place.’
ud6.4:17.4: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ that man replied. He did as the king asked, then said to him,
ud6.4:17.5: ‘Your Majesty, the blind people throughout Sāvatthī have been gathered.’
ud6.4:17.6: ‘Well then, my man, show them an elephant.’
ud6.4:17.7: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ that man replied. He did as the king asked.
ud6.4:18.1: To some of the blind people he showed the elephant’s head, saying,
ud6.4:18.3: To some of them he showed the elephant’s ear, saying,
ud6.4:18.5: To some of them he showed the elephant’s tusk, saying,
ud6.4:18.7: To some of them he showed the elephant’s trunk, saying,
ud6.4:18.9: To some of them he showed the elephant’s flank, saying,
ud6.4:18.11: To some of them he showed the elephant’s leg, saying,
ud6.4:18.13: To some of them he showed the elephant’s thigh, saying,
ud6.4:18.15: To some of them he showed the elephant’s tail, saying,
ud6.4:18.17: To some of them he showed the tip of the elephant’s tail, saying,
ud6.4:19.1: Then he approached the king and said,
ud6.4:19.2: ‘Your Majesty, the blind people have been shown the elephant.
ud6.4:20.1: Then the king went up to the blind people and said,
ud6.4:20.3: ‘Yes, Your Majesty, we have been shown the elephant.’
ud6.4:20.4: ‘Then tell us, what kind of thing is an elephant?’
ud6.4:21.1: The blind people who had been shown the elephant’s head said,
ud6.4:21.2: ‘Your Majesty, an elephant is like a pot.’
ud6.4:22.1: Those who had been shown the ear said,
ud6.4:22.2: ‘An elephant is like a winnowing fan.’
ud6.4:23.1: Those who had been shown the tusk said,
ud6.4:24.1: Those who had been shown the trunk said,
ud6.4:25.1: Those who had been shown the flank said,
ud6.4:26.1: Those who had been shown the leg said,
ud6.4:27.1: Those who had been shown the thigh said,
ud6.4:28.1: Those who had been shown the tail said,
ud6.4:29.1: Those who had been shown the tip of the tail said,
ud6.4:30.1: Saying, ‘Such is an elephant, not such!
ud6.4:30.2: Such is not an elephant, such is!’ they punched each other with their fists.
ud6.4:30.3: At that, the king was pleased.
ud6.4:31.1: In the same way, mendicants, the wanderers of other religions are blind and sightless.
ud6.4:31.2: They don’t understand what is beneficial or what is not beneficial, nor what is the truth and what is not the truth.
ud6.4:31.3: That’s why they are fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
ud6.4:31.5: Such is not Truth, such is!’”
ud6.4:32.1: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ud6.4:33.4: the folk who see just one part.”
